> 
Sent:
 Thursday, August 31, 2023 8:32 AM
To:
 Daniel Gough <
d.gough@lcwmail.com
>; Tamara Thorpe <
t.thorpe@lcwmail.com
>; Andrea Wicks Bowles <
a.wicksbowles@lcwmail.com
>; Chuck Adams <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RESPONSE: How to Disrupt Your Bias When Evaluating Talent
 
Hi, y’all.  
 
I worked on a proposal for a 
prospect who was interested in a session re: managing bias in performance reviews
. 
I knew we’d built a 30-min session for Carta on this topic (they’re unique in wanting these very short sessions) but as I reviewed the slides, I realized it’s a lot of content for 30 minutes, and could be 
extended to an hour largely by allowing more discussion time
. 
I also think offering a half hour course is a bit odd in the context of the rest of our workshops, 
one hour seems more appropriate
. 
So I ended up quoting the one hour price for this session, thinking
 that if we get it, we’d put in the relatively light work of expanding it to an hour
. 
What do you think?
 
I would 
recommend selling this workshop as a hour going forward
, as it more closely aligns with our miniworkshops, for example. 
We’d have to change the pricing, as well as the description, from 30 min to 1 hour, in both Compass and HubSpot.
 
This is the workshop I’m talking about:
 
 
 
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
(she/her)
Head of Business Development
LCW

subject: RE: IT Invoices
body:
Hey,
 
It looks like being an admin in dropbox/MS is a good thing. Some stuff in the invoices we’d still need to reach out for since it’s more technical. But a lot of it is easy stuff we’re spending like $30 each for (like giving someone access to a folder or email groups in outlook).
 
Computer set up seems high, I don’t think I saw storage costs on there(?) but that may be high too. But, if we want that outsourced I guess that’s just the cost.
 
Shipping is probably better if we just do it through Fedex.com when people leave.
 
From:
 Briza Cardenas <b.cardenas@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, August 30, 2023 11:02 AM
To:
 Kendall Washington <k.washington@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 IT Invoices
 
Hey Kendall,
 
Take a look at these IT invoices. A lot of the stuff we get charged for we could easily do. I’m an admin in Dropbox and can add/delete/pause people.
Nicole used to be an admin for Microsoft, I asked Elijah a few months ago if he could make me one and he said no. I forgot the reason and can’t find the email. But this was before I officially took over so maybe that’s why. 
 
I think we should only use them when there are computer malfunctions, wiping computers, etc. things we can’t fix on our own. 
Everything else, including box shipments should be handled by us. 
 
Let me know your thoughts on this. 
 
Briza Cardenas  
(she/her)

 Podcast Updates
 
Good morning, podcast team!
 
I have two updates for you today:
 
I wrote to Patricia last week but never heard back. I’m wondering if maybe my email went to her junk mail folder. 
@Larry
, could you reach out to her and confirm she’s still interested/received my email? 
I told Maria our idea for an LCW translation spotlight and she agreed to be on the podcast… but it turns out she already asked two translators if they want to be on our podcast and they said yes. I don’t know how we’re feeling about 3 guests per podcast – that seems pretty packed! What do you think? I think I’ll set up a meeting with all of us so we can hash out the details…
 
That’s all for now. 
😊
 
Ashton

subject: Refresh Your Skills with the New Zoom Learning Center Experience
body:
Register today for Zoomtopia, running oct. 3-4.
Hi there,  
The Zoom Learning Center (ZLC) has a new look! We have refreshed the homepage to make onboarding and ongoing learning as easy as possible, including: 
New specialized tracks for administrators and end users 
Banner and static announcements to let you know what’s happening 
Quick access to the latest resources for ongoing learning opportunities 
And more! 
Why not refresh the basics by following the 
Zoom Admin Onboarding
 learning plan from your 
Start Your Onboarding
 page to achieve your onboarding certificate? Be sure to pass this information on to your end users as well, so they can take advantage of the 
Zoom User Onboarding
 learning plan created specifically for them! 
VISIT THE NEW ZLC EXPERIENCE
 
If you have any questions as you explore the ZLC, please feel free to reach out. We’re happy to help! 
Zoom Customer Success Advisor Team

Subject:

Hello LCW,
 
As some of you may have heard, Sarah and her family have received incredibly difficult news this week. Her husband, Tony, is transitioning into hospice care. While we recognize that there's only so much we can do to ease this challenging time, we are committed to offering our support where we can. 
 
Our plan is to send them a Grubhub gift card, which will help alleviate the burden of meal preparation and planning.
If any of you are interested in contributing and increasing the amount we are purchasing, I've included my cash app details below and intend to make the purchase tomorrow afternoon.
 
Zelle: 
brizabreeze@gmail.com
Venmo: Briza Cardenas
 
Thank you all for jumping in to cover Sarah’s work responsibilities while she and her family go through this difficult time.
 
Briza Cardenas  
(she/her)

subject: Sarah Update & LCW Support
body:
Hello LCW,
 
As some of you may have heard, Sarah and her family have received incredibly difficult news this week. Her husband, Tony, is transitioning into hospice care. While we recognize that there's only so much we can do to ease this challenging time, we are committed to offering our support where we can. 
 
Our plan is to send them a Grubhub gift card, which will help alleviate the burden of meal preparation and planning.
If any of you are interested in contributing and increasing the amount we are purchasing, I've included my cash app details below and intend to make the purchase tomorrow afternoon.
 
Zelle: 
brizabreeze@gmail.com
Venmo: Briza Cardenas
 
Thank you all for jumping in to cover Sarah’s work responsibilities while she and her family go through this difficult time.
 
Briza Cardenas  
(she/her)
Chief of Staff, Office of the CEO
LCW

subject: Check out ongoing training for Zoom Events, Webinars and Sessions
body:
Hi there,
Last month, we hosted several live training sessions for Zoom Events, Webinars, and Sessions. Due to popular demand, we will now offer ongoing training sessions and a monthly discussion of the latest features for these Zoom products! 
To stay up to date, make sure you bookmark the 
Zoom Events Training hub
 and check back regularly for new sessions.  
Get started by registering for the 
Zoom Events: Monthly Release Discussion and Q&A on August 30 at 11 am PT / 2 pm ET
. Our team of experts will walk you through the latest release and highlight key benefits for a variety of event use cases, including: 
Internal communication 
Marketing  
Customer training events  
And more!  
Register for Monthly Release Discussion
 
Don’t forget to share these details with the internal teams that use Zoom Events, Webinars, and Sessions. We look forward to seeing you there! 
Happy Zooming,  
Customer Success Advisor Team
Zoom Learning Center

I managed to sort out most of it! However, I do have a lingering concern. The billable work for Translation isn't accurate, as only Diligent is listed. We're missing entries for all the translation clients, such as Alliant and Catalent. Although I recorded all that work under Diligent for my own timekeeping and reference, I believe this needs to be corrected.
Furthermore, I noticed that each Statement of Work (SOW) is properly listed for the consultants, allowing them to track their time effectively for each project. We lack this breakdown for translation. Currently, all billables are lumped under Diligent's general category, with no distinction by translation client or SOW (Scoro Quote number). Please let me know who I should reach out to enter more billable categories for translation. I will be happy to enter them as well each time a project is approved after quoting.

subject: New information: JWT retirement schedule change
body:
Dear Valued Customer, 
Due to the U.S. holiday weekend 
we are moving the JSON Web Token (JWT) app type retirement to Sept. 8 for all customers
. For details on how to navigate this change, please review our 
JWT deprecation guide
. If you are not using the JWT app type in Zoom Marketplace then no action is required. 
NOTE: Our online documentation is currently in the process of being updated to reflect the new deprecation date of Sept 8. 
On Sept. 8, Zoom will start the phased deactivation of JWT apps across all customer accounts. Due to the large number of accounts impacted it could take several days before your JWT app is deactivated. You will be notified by email when the deactivation occurs in your account.
To avoid disruption, you must migrate 
to a Server-to-Server or OAuth implementation
 before Sept. 8.  
For instructions on how to migrate specific integrations, please see the guides below:  
Azure SCIM
Salesforce for Zoom App
Epic
 and 
Epic FHIR
Zoom Rooms JSON RPC API
If you are currently using a third-party integration that uses JWT and is not listed above, we recommend reaching out to the developer for more information on their migration plan. 
You have the ability to remove a JWT app from your account. If you’re actively using the JWT app type, we recommend following these steps before you consider removing the JWT app:
Review the call logs for your JWT app
.
Follow the 
migration guide
, or the 
instructional webinar
 to migrate your apps.
When your apps have been migrated, or if you believe there will be no business impact, we recommend that you deactivate your JWT app for a period of time. The JWT app can be reactivated if necessary.
When you’re confident the JWT app is no longer needed you can remove the app from your account. Removing the app will permanently delete it from your account.
⚠️ IMPORTANT: There is no way to recover/restore the JWT app once it’s been removed. ⚠️ 
For any additional questions, please see the 
JWT migration guide
, 
JWT deprecation FAQ
 or you can reach out to our 
developer advocacy or support teams
.
​​​​​
Team Zoom 
 
Catch us on social 
 
 
 
 
 
Visit 
zoom.us
1-888-799-9666
55 Almaden Blvd., San Jose, CA 95113
© 2023 Zoom - All Rights Reserved 
 
 
Click 
here
 to unsubscribe from this list or manage your preferences 
here
.

From:
 Dustin Puehler <
d.puehler@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Thursday, August 3, 2023 10:09 AM
To:
 Office <
office@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Updated Microlearnings with REBRANDING
 
Good morning everyone,
 
We’ve updated and rebranded our microlearning courses below. I would HIGHLY encourage for each person to revisit each of these Microlearnings over the next two weeks and see how these subjects can work to diversify your asset offerings for your client’s Learning Journey. If you have any questions, concerns, or ideas, please send them my way. 
 
Our recent collaborations with Ralph Lauren reminded us how these assets can be strategically “customized” for clients for maximum $ while capturing their company culture using image swaps and color branding. If you would like to analyze any course and it’s client solution possibilities, feel free to schedule a meeting with me. We can do a deeper dive on any singular course to improve our overall generic version or chat strategies for customizing to client needs. 
 
You can find these links also in the Resources for Consultants within Teams.
 
MICROLEARNINGS
 
Username: 
test@lcwmail.com 
Expiration Date (for all below links): 
12/31/2023
 
 
 
 
Managing Bias in Performance Reviews
 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=3c9eeb1e-3d2b-4494-8163-b9ff1283b75c
 
In this short (10-15 minute) course
,
 you’ll learn how to become more aware of personal biases so that we can attend to them and interrupt them while evaluating our team members’ performance and conducting performance reviews.  
Managing Bias in Talent Reviews
 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=bf8f5de8-98ae-478b-9a71-6269d1e8e9d2
 
In this short (10-15 minute) course
,
 you’ll learn ways to reduce your bias in the talent review process so that you can promote diversity, inclusion, and objectivity, and mitigate unconscious bias that may be hampering your best intentions when it comes to reviewing talent.  
Managing Bias in Hiring
 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=09ace2b6-9d23-4039-981f-06c46182d5c6
 
This short (10-15 minute)
 
course allows us to become aware of our biases so that we can attend to them and interrupt them while evaluating and selecting diverse top talent. 
Managing Bias in Interviewing
 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=fe85349c-cb6a-4bf7-85dc-d99f3e912840
 
In this short (10-15 minute) course
,
 you’ll learn ways to mitigate unconscious biases during job interviews, so that you can promote diversity, inclusion, and objectivity and mitigate biases that may be undermining your best intentions when it comes to interviewing job candidates.  
Managing Bias in Recruiting
 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=f1332bc6-0368-472e-a986-7fd93616f071
 
In this short (10-15 minute) course, you’ll learn ways to mitigate unconscious biases during the talent sourcing and recruitment process, so that you can find and recognize diverse top talent more effectively.  
 
 
Best,
 
 
Dustin Puehler
Senior Manager of Multimedia Development
LCW

subject: FW: Updated Microlearnings with REBRANDING
body:
Hey there! 
 
Briza submitted some feedback for our rebranded courses below. Would you mind making them to the Rise courses we updated. When you’re done just ping me and then I’ll republish them for the website. 
 
Just let me know if you’re busy and I can add it to my list. Thanks!
 
Dustin
 
From:
 Briza Cardenas <b.cardenas@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Monday, August 14, 2023 4:16 PM
To:
 Dustin Puehler <d.puehler@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Updated Microlearnings with REBRANDING
 
Hi Dustin,
 
I went through 3/5 micolearnings you sent out. Below are my edits. I’ll get to the rest tomorrow. 
 
 
Managing Bias in Talent Reviews:
Lesson 3 of 4
 
 
With some suggestions on 
how
 to avoid them:
 
Managing Bias in Hiring
Interviewers is split into two words. 
 
Lesson 3 of 4
I could be imagining this but looks like there is a double space at the end of this passage after crucially, …
 
Also, the url to our website is different.
We are lcwinclusion.com now. 
 
 
 
Briza Cardenas  
(she/her)
Chief of Staff, Office of the CEO
LCW

 |

From:
 Dustin Puehler <
d.puehler@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Thursday, August 3, 2023 10:09 AM
To:
 Office <
office@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Updated Microlearnings with REBRANDING
 
Good morning everyone,
 
We’ve updated and rebranded our microlearning courses below. I would HIGHLY encourage for each person to revisit each of these Microlearnings over the next two weeks and see how these subjects can work to diversify your asset offerings for your client’s Learning Journey. If you have any questions, concerns, or ideas, please send them my way. 
 
Our recent collaborations with Ralph Lauren reminded us how these assets can be strategically “customized” for clients for maximum $ while capturing their company culture using image swaps and color branding. If you would like to analyze any course and it’s client solution possibilities, feel free to schedule a meeting with me. We can do a deeper dive on any singular course to improve our overall generic version or chat strategies for customizing to client needs. 
 
You can find these links also in the Resources for Consultants within Teams.
 
MICROLEARNINGS
 
Username: 
test@lcwmail.com 
Expiration Date (for all below links): 
12/31/2023
 
 
 
 
Managing Bias in Performance Reviews
 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=3c9eeb1e-3d2b-4494-8163-b9ff1283b75c
 
In this short (10-15 minute) course
,
 you’ll learn how to become more aware of personal biases so that we can attend to them and interrupt them while evaluating our team members’ performance and conducting performance reviews.  
Managing Bias in Talent Reviews
 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=bf8f5de8-98ae-478b-9a71-6269d1e8e9d2
 
In this short (10-15 minute) course
,
 you’ll learn ways to reduce your bias in the talent review process so that you can promote diversity, inclusion, and objectivity, and mitigate unconscious bias that may be hampering your best intentions when it comes to reviewing talent.  
Managing Bias in Hiring
 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=09ace2b6-9d23-4039-981f-06c46182d5c6
 
This short (10-15 minute)
 
course allows us to become aware of our biases so that we can attend to them and interrupt them while evaluating and selecting diverse top talent. 
Managing Bias in Interviewing
 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=fe85349c-cb6a-4bf7-85dc-d99f3e912840
 
In this short (10-15 minute) course
,
 you’ll learn ways to mitigate unconscious biases during job interviews, so that you can promote diversity, inclusion, and objectivity and mitigate biases that may be undermining your best intentions when it comes to interviewing job candidates.  
Managing Bias in Recruiting
 
https://app.cloud.scorm.com/sc/InvitationConfirmEmail?publicInvitationId=f1332bc6-0368-472e-a986-7fd93616f071
 
In this short (10-15 minute) course, you’ll learn ways to mitigate unconscious biases during the talent sourcing and recruitment process, so that you can find and recognize diverse top talent more effectively.  
 
 
Best,
 
 
Dustin Puehler
Senior Manager of Multimedia Development
LCW

subject: Podcast Conversation
body:
Hello all!
 
I’m scheduling some time for us to brainstorm what we’d like the rest of our podcast season to look like. Maria also had a request for a podcast featuring translation, so we can discuss that too. 
😊
 
Come with your ideas and any coded phrases you’d like us to touch on that we haven’t yet! As a reminder, here are all the episodes we recorded so far:
“Where are you really from?” – Greg Sloan
“You’re not being a team player.” – Rahimeh Ramezany
“You’re just a diversity hire.” – Ana Goehner
“But you don’t look autistic.” – Becca Lory Hector
“I don’t see color.” – Paul Ladipo
“You need to watch your tone.” – Ralinda Watts
“You’re being too woke.” – Dana Brownlee
 
Looking forward to chatting!
Ashton

subject: 3+ tips for your next meeting
body:
View in browser
 
Master meeting facilitation
We know it takes more than just a poll question to run engaging meetings. There’s a lot of work behind 
screens
 scenes to be done - plus essential skills to learn along the way.
We’re here to provide simple practices you can use to deliver the best meeting experience. One step at a time. 
How to include remote attendees? 👥
Try to keep a remote-first mindset. Address questions towards them first, include them in the conversation and make sure they hear everyone present in the room. Master the hybrid setup with our 
22 tips
.
How to keep the discussion on point? 🗣
You might not be aware of your attendee's expectations. To find out what people want to focus on and to make your meetings more democratic, run a 
ranking poll
 with the proposed agenda topics.
I've launched my poll, now what? 🤔
Give attendees time before going through the results. Read aloud some of the submissions and ask volunteers to share insights regarding their answers. Some days people won’t want to speak up, and that's okay. You can always use the submissions as a bridge to your next point within the meeting.
To see 
commenting in action
, check out the recording from our 
The Art of Meeting Facilitation
 webinar. 🎥
 
Start with an icebreaker
They help energize people, drive lively discussions and encourage participants to be more active throughout the meeting. 
Get inspired
.
Prepare your Slido
 
What to watch out for
Awkward silence
 😰
Give your audience time to process information. You can use those pauses to comment on poll results or encourage the less vocal participants to speak up and join the discussion.
Attendees' attention span
 😴
Is everyone keeping up? A rating poll will help to understand where you stand and confidently move through your agenda.
Overloaded slides
 ⚖️
Make sure your slides are not too content-heavy. Clear slides with snappy short sentences help make the content stick. 
Made with 
 by Slido

Our Blog
 | 
Contact Us
 | 
Privacy Statement
 |

subject: From Day One: The Great Moderation
body:
As the months of 2023 have ticked by, the Great Resignation has quietly lost something: its greatness. The worker resignation rate in June fell to 2.4%, essentially returning to where it was in June 2019. For employers who had been in a war for talent, the dramatic lack of turnover has brought welcome relief. But what does that mean for workers, who in 2020-22 enjoyed a wealth of new benefits, job flexibility, and employer concern about their well-being? Will employers start taking workers for granted?
 
While HR experts say that most employers won’t be inclined to turn the clock back to 2019, workers will see a more miserly approach. In terms of total rewards, you could call it the Great Moderation. “Employee retention at all costs–in terms of very high salaries; PTO and other employee perks–is over,” Janine Yancey, CEO of the corporate-culture platform 
Emtrain
, told From Day One. While she believes that job flexibility and pay equity are here to stay, “we’re moving into a time of scarcity, not abundance, which impacts the employee experience.”
 
We're working with AARP to increase age inclusion, and we need your help. Please fill out 
this very short, three-question survey
 to let us know what actions your organization is undertaking or wants to undertake to support workers of all ages.
 
The Great Resignation’s obituary was written earlier this month, when the management professor who coined the term in 2021, Anthony Klotz,
 told 
Fast Company
, “I believe the Great Resignation has largely come to an end.” Added Klotz, who is now a professor at University College London’s School of Management: “The backlog of quitting has certainly cleared.”
 
Why They’re Staying
 
Employee surveys indicate that workers are motivated to stay in their jobs by a mixture of caution and the need for a calm stretch of time. The massive layoffs early in the pandemic, followed by the wave of austerity-inspired layoffs in the last year, have made workers less inclined to be job-hopping if they trust their situation.
 
At the same time, they're overdue for some R and R for the sake of their sanity. “We are now in a time when stability and routine are supporting mental-health needs as many recover from the shock of unplanned life/work changes,” Laura Sewell, EVP of North American HR for the IT services consultancy 
Avanade
, told From Day One. “It has only been in the past 12 to 18 months that more and more people have begun planning vacations, events, and other activities which were put on hold during the pandemic. Having access to paid time off through their employer offers them both the time they need and the financial backing to finally take those trips and plan the events.”
 
Why Employers Are Tightening Up
 
The combination of high interest rates and slow economic growth have inspired companies to clamp down on spending as well as hiring. “2023 has been the year of massive downsizing across the board,” observes Yancey. “Capital is scarce and capital fuels business growth, so that will impact job growth. Businesses are focused on showing profitability first and foremost.”
 
How will the austerity mindset affect employee benefits? That issue has caused tension between finance departments and HR leaders who just recently had been working overtime to create new incentives to attract and retain employees, including programs to support worker well-being and family caregiving. “We’re in this constant battle with finance,” said Ken Wechsler, VP of total rewards at Akamai Technologies, in a recent From Day One webinar on employee benefits. “We’re fighting for it, and I guess my colleagues on this call will also fight it.”
 
Which Workplace Improvements Will Endure
 
Part of the reason for low turnover right now, Avanade’s Sewell points out, is the enhanced working conditions that were inspired by the hardships of the pandemic. “Over the past three years, inclusion and well-being have rocketed to the top of our people priorities. With this increased focus, employees are feeling better supported at work, have access to more resources and benefits to take care of themselves, and in general, most have greater flexibility in how and where they get their work done.”
 
Despite well-publicized efforts by some major employers, notably in finance, to bring workers back to the office for a majority of the workweek, job flexibility is a value that has become well-embedded in the expectations of most workers. Asserted Emtrain’s Yancey: “I believe the need for job flexibility is here to stay and employer's obligation to create jobs with pay equity and a healthy, inclusive work culture is here to stay.”
 
So is the inclination for workers to negotiate their terms. “Everything is in play now­–things I had never even thought of when it comes to total rewards,” said Akamai’s Wechsler. “We give employees the choice of where they want to work, and 90% of them have said they want to work from home.”  
 
Trying to Reach an Equilibrium
 
While turnover may be low at the moment, forward-looking employers know that future job shortages driven by an aging population and new attitudes toward work mean that they can’t forget the lessons learned during the Great Resignation. “It’s a new culture of work,” behavioral scientist Laurel McKenzie told 
Fast Company
’s AJ Hess. “No one’s staying at organizations for years and years. People are willing to leave and find something better. There’s not a sense of loyalty to organizations anymore. People are more focused on taking care of themselves and finding organizations that will enable that.”
 
Avanade’s Sewell says her company keeps close tabs on surveys to pick up on trends in employee sentiment. “Our goal is to maintain the hearts and minds of our employees through all of the ups and downs and be prepared for what is ahead. By building loyalty now, we are creating a stronger foundation for whatever wave comes next.”
 
In a book to be published next month,
 
The Retention Revolution: 7 Surprising (and Very Human!) Ways to Keep Employees Connected to Your Company
, workplace strategist and bestselling author Erica Keswin calls for a new paradigm in thinking about the relationship between workers and employers, as well as career pathways “The time is now to reconsider everything we know about the employee journey and why linear thinking is being replaced by the more human reality of cycles, revolving doors, and dynamic change.” 
Read the full story here
.
  
FEATURE
  
Older Workers and Technology: How They Approach It With a Different Mindset: 
Karen Fleshman is a 54-year-old CEO of a small
 workshop-facilitation company
 based in the world’s tech capital, the San Francisco Bay Area. Recently, a potential client approached her about creating some anti-harassment videos, but before they would award her company the contract, they wanted to see a sample. Fleshman’s expertise is content, not tech. To win the job, she would need to deliver both. “I was like, ‘Oh God, this is not something I can record on my phone,” said Fleshman. “I’m really going to have to work to make this look up to their standards.” Video creation and artificial intelligence is new territory for Fleshman—for the project, she’s teaching herself Descript, Loom, StreamYard, and Beautiful.ai—but resourcefulness comes naturally. 
Read the full story here
.
  
LIVE CONFERENCE HIGHLIGHTS
  
From Recruitment to Advancement: How to Keep Momentum Going on Diversity and Inclusion: 
84% of CHROs say that their organizations are increasing investment in diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging (DEIB) initiatives. But only 31% of employees say that their organization is committed to improving equity in the workplace, according to a Gallup poll conducted in the spring of 2022. Workplace diversity is experiencing a disconnect. Shawna Chen, a reporter for 
Axios
, moderated a panel of experts on this issue at From Day One’s 
San Francisco conference
. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
The Culture of H-E-B: Why Employees (and Customers) Are So Devoted: 
Texans don’t say, “We’re going grocery shopping.” They say, “We’re going to H-E-B.” Mayerland Harris, group VP of talent at 
H-E-B
, said the reason is all about the company’s values: “Doing what’s right simply because it’s the right thing to do, not for the accolades and not for profit, but to help our community.” H-E-B employs about 154,000 employees in more than 430 stores in Texas and Mexico. Doing what’s right plays out in how the company treats its employees, called “partners,” as well as suppliers and customers. Harris spoke with Dan Goodgame, editor in chief of 
Texas Monthly
, in a fireside chat at From Day One’s 
Austin conference
. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
Putting Talent Where It’s Needed: Companies Search Internally to Find Ways to Close Skills Gaps: 
When 
USAA
’s Head of Talent Marketplace Lya Icaza reflects on her early career, she remembers being advised not to mention her family heritage in the workplace. Icaza and a panel of four other female leaders used their experiences and business knowledge to highlight how companies can better foster career growth among employees during the 
Austin conference
. “[In previous workplaces,] if I had gone to my leader and said, ‘Hey, I think I want to go work for somebody else,’ then [I’d be] terminated tomorrow,” said Ramona Arora, chief learning officer and VPof global talent and development at 
Dell
. “That talent-hoarding mentality, that's part of a culture.” A culture that all five women were happy to report is becoming increasingly scarce in the 21st century. 
Read the full story here
. 
  
VIRTUAL EVENT HIGHLIGHTS
  
Making Health and Well-Being a Priority for Workers and Their Families: 
Imagine going to your employer for bereavement time to process the loss of a loved one and being denied. At 
Northwell Health
, this wouldn’t happen. Their bereavement policy is more inclusive than other more traditional approaches, thanks to the organization’s broader commitment to the health and well-being of its diverse workforce. Northwell Health is a nonprofit, integrated network that is New York State's largest healthcare provider and private employer, with more than 81,000 employees. At 
From Day One’s July virtual conference
 on family health, Gregg Nevola, VP and chief rewards officer at Northwell Health, detailed the organization’s policies. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
Bridging the Distance: How Tech Can Boost Engagement and Recognition: 
Picture an all-hands meeting with hundreds of employees, and a team leader singling out a shy employee to congratulate them–but totally horrifying them in the process! If only the manager had known, they could have rewarded the employee in a way that made them feel comfortable. Learning employee preferences and demeanors can be hard, especially in a large, distributed workforce. How can employers promote cohesion while helping employees feel seen by managers and peers? In a panel at the 
July conference
, business leaders discussed the best technologies and practices. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
Neurodiversity in Families: Innovative Ways for Employers to Support Parents: 
There are more than 11 million children with special needs in the U.S., according to 
the National Institutes of Health
. For the parents of those children, the responsibilities are many and often changing—family life is different, which means their work life will be different too. How can employers make it better? “Parents will tell me, I don’t need pity, I don’t need sympathy,” said Angela Nelson, executive director of clinical services at 
RethinkCare
, a virtual platform for behavior and mental health needs. What they do need, she says, is flexibility, reassurance, and recognition. As part of the 
July conference
, four leaders in HR and clinical mental health explored ways to support families affected by neurodivergence. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
Solving a Universal Domestic Problem: Unequal Labor in the Home Front: 
“There is no nation on this planet where men do more unpaid labor than women,” said Eve Rodsky, author of 
Fair Play: A Game-Changing Solution for When You Have Too Much to Do (and More Life to Live).
 Women still do more than two-thirds of domestic work, says Rodsky, a mother, wife, and attorney. Lila Seidman, reporter at the Los Angeles Times, interviewed Rodsky during the 
July conference
. Their discussion started with a screening of 
the trailer
 of Jennifer Siebel Newson’s documentary based on Rodsky’s book. “I felt I was the default for every single domestic task in my family,” said Rodsky in the video. Frustrated, she set out to research women’s labor in the household around the world. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
Why Culture Is the Solution for Employee Well-Being and Performance: Six Building Blocks for Success: 
When Dr. Richard Safeer, author and chief medical director of employee health and well-being at Johns Hopkins Medicine, was starting out as a doctor, he noticed his stressed-out patients were neglecting exercise and nutrition. “Most of the people who were coming into my office probably wouldn't have needed to be there, if they only knew what they could do themselves to have a healthier day,” Safeer said. This discovery led him to his current role, and to write the book 
A Cure for the Common Company: A Well-Being Prescription for a Happier, Healthier, and More Resilient Workforce.
 Journalist Kelly Bourdet interviewed Safeer in a fireside chat at the 
July conference
 to learn more. 
Read the full story here
.
  
QUICK HITS
  
Inside Starbucks’ Dirty War Against Organized Labor:
 Hectic, high-risk pandemic shifts racked up record profits for Starbucks but left many of the baristas exhausted. Workers at one cafe after the next voted to unionize–more than 330 of its thousands of locations so far. Their demands include better pay ($20 an hour minimum for baristas, with annual raises), fair and consistent scheduling, and easier access to the benefits that Starbucks executives have always touted. In this context, 
The New York Times 
reports, a Nottingham, Md., Starbucks voted to join Starbucks Workers United in June 2022–and Agnes Torregoza and her colleagues stepped into a world of trouble. The corporate dirty war that ensued in Nottingham and at newly unionized Starbucks cafes across the country draws a sobering picture of employee rights casually crushed and labor laws too weak to help. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
Research: Caregiver Employees Bring Unique Value to Companies: 
There is no lack of data about why organizations should offer 
caregiver-friendly policies and benefits
. Still, the U.S. lacks the infrastructure to support caregivers and is the only industrial nation without federal paid parental leave. Many people live in 
childcare deserts
. Given these shortcomings and the fact that 
73% of U.S. employees
 are caregivers, in order to have a productive and sustainable workforce, companies must create the 
infrastructure
 to support them. Not supporting caregivers results in high turnover, lost institutional knowledge, and absenteeism. 
Harvard Business Review 
published research that shows how caregivers bring skills that improve culture, retention, and the bottom line. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
Do Oddball Questions Help Companies Find the Best New Hires? Unlikely: 
“Which one of the seven dwarfs would you be?” Dismiss that question at your peril. Silly or not, such questions are increasingly common in job interviews. So common, in fact, that Don Zhang, associate professor of industrial and organizational psychology at Louisiana State University, decided to examine how candidates perceive these questions and the companies asking them. “I came across all these questions, and I thought, ‘What do companies think they are accomplishing when they ask these,’ and, ‘How would an applicant feel,’ ” Zhang told 
The Wall Street Journal
. He found that companies might be better off cutting the quirky. 
Read the full story here
. 
  
SPONSOR SPOTLIGHTS
  
REGENERATE
 
 
How a Gen Z Advocate Applies Science to Help His Generation Thrive: 
Leaders in today’s workplaces desire to better understand the motivations, aspirations, and values of Generation Z. Harrison Bach finds himself with a unique and timely opportunity to deliver on that desire. Bach, 23, is a student of his contemporaries in his role as the client engagement manager for 
Regenerate
, a training and consulting firm that leverages the science of human energy to help leaders work and live more sustainably. While generational labels don’t apply to everyone, Gen Z, 
generally defined
 as those born between 1997 and 2012, has acquired a reputation for 
several defining characteristics
. This fall, Bach will lead a workshop on managing Gen Z at From Day One’s 
September virtual conference
. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
NPOWER
 
The Keys to Attracting Diverse Talent in the Tech World: 
The path to tech was anything but traditional for Dana Morrow Branch, VP of systems engineering for 
Bank of America
. Branch became a self-taught coder by spending her free time on a computer in the library of her high school. In her explorations, Branch not only accidentally broke into Maryland’s Board of Education database but also discovered her knack for coding. Branch’s path to success proved that not all skills need to be learned from a textbook or professor. In the webinar “
Attracting Non-traditional and Diverse Talent
,” moderator Jonathan Pride, executive director of 
NPower
, spoke with Branch and other leaders on how tech workers can break from the traditional career path and how employers attract skilled talent in the current market. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
DDI
 
The Evolving Role of Leaders in Enhancing Employee Engagement: 
Lots of companies talk about well-being, but many don’t follow through in a tangible way. Rosey Rhyne, senior research manager at 
DDI
, a global leadership-development firm, recommends that leaders should walk the walk–sometimes literally. “For a leader, showing how they prioritize wellness could mean saying, ‘I’m going for a walk to clear my head after this busy morning.’ It’s about doing little things where well-being is a priority that is being communicated,” said Rhyne. “Doing that really shows vulnerability, too.” Showing vulnerability helps build 
trust
, an intangible yet crucial aspect of leadership. According to DDI’s recently published 
Global Leadership Forecast 2023
, when leaders regularly display vulnerability, employees are five times more likely to trust them. From Day One talked with Rhyne, who contributed to the research, to learn more. 
Read the full story here
. 
 
15FIVE
 
Manager Effectiveness as the Path to Individual and Organizational Success: 
“People don’t quit companies, they quit managers.” Adam Bouse, manager of performance coaching at 
15Five
, often hears this saying in business circles. But he’d amend that quote: “People don’t quit companies, they quit managers who haven’t been set up to succeed,” he said during 
From Day One’s July virtual conference.
 Bouse spoke on manager effectiveness as the path to individual and organizational success. While it’s not uncommon for employees to criticize direct superiors due to unsatisfactory work conditions, Bouse said 15Five looks higher up the ladder to help reverse negative trends such as voluntary turnover. “The majority of managers want to be good at their job,” he said. “Most managers come in with the best intentions. They simply haven’t been given the training, coaching and tools to succeed.” 
Read the full story here
. 
  
  
UPCOMING EVENTS
  
WEBINARS
 
Get credit! From Day One is accredited by the professional organizations SHRM and HRCI, and most of our sessions qualify for professional development credit from both organizations. See our individual event-registration pages for credit details. 
 
Aug. 22: The Future of Talent Acquisition: Perfecting the Human Experience in the Age of AI. 
To consider more candidates and reduce the most time-intensive parts of recruiting, innovative employers leverage emerging automation technologies to build more diverse, high-performing teams. Thanks to these new technologies, employers are now able to cast a wider net when they need to, as well as create an effective screen when they have an abundance of candidates. For employers, what are the steps toward modernizing their approach? What benefits can they expect to see in both early career and experienced recruiting approaches? And how can HR practitioners 
really 
do more with less to hit their hiring goals while strengthening the human experiences for candidates and new hires? 
Register now
. 
 
Aug. 24: The Economic Impact of Family-Care Support: A Case Study. 
What is the value of a well-designed family care program for all employees? With diverse, multi-generational workforces, many companies are now seeing the need to support their entire population with more personalized family care–and seeking data to make the case and measure value. In this fireside chat, we’ll explore the path taken by Okta, a $2 billion identity-security company, to provide inclusive, global family care for its 6,000 employees. You’ll hear firsthand about the company’s goals, what its leaders learned, and how they measured and demonstrated value. 
Register now
. 
 
Aug. 29: The Benefits of Sleep Care: Curbing the Progression and Costs of Multiple Chronic Conditions. 
Troubled sleep among employees may not seem as urgent to address as heart disease, hypertension, or diabetes. But what’s often overlooked is that lack of sleep is a major aggravator of chronic conditions, worsening the outlook for patients and driving up total health care costs. People with sleep disorders cost three times more for their health care than people without them. For example, 9 out 10 people with sleep apnea also have one or more simultaneous chronic conditions. While troubled sleep is often a hidden issue, the care gap it creates can be bridged with effective sleep health management. Traditional programs typically don’t work, but this webinar will show how a value-based program puts the patient in the center of care, improving their health outcome, lowering costs, and reducing wasted effort. You’ll learn how lasting patient results can be delivered through multidisciplinary teamwork and an outcomes-focused, clinically integrated delivery system. 
Register now
. 
 
Sept. 13: Using AI to Revolutionize Hiring for Top Talent, While Avoiding the Pitfalls. 
For talent acquisition, AI presents a remarkable tool that can help by verifying candidates’ backgrounds and skills, suggesting interview questions, creating candidate profiles, and other tasks. As tech hiring picks up, especially for AI roles, how can TA leaders make the best use of the new technology, while also being on the alert for candidates using AI fraudulently during skills assessments? How can TA specialists use AI to solve many of their pain points, while continuing to focus on the aspects of the job that require the human touch? 
Register now
. 
 
Sept. 14: What Employers Need to Know About Chronic Kidney Disease: Its Rising Prevalence, Its High Cost, and How to Manage It. 
Chronic kidney disease (CKD) has become increasingly common, affecting one in seven U.S. adults, yet most people won't know they have it until it has reached an advanced stage. This can present significant challenges for workers, who may have to undergo dialysis or other treatments, and for employers, who may face shockingly high-cost medical claims. This webinar will educate attendees about CKD and provide practical insights to address this condition within an employer’s benefits strategy. You'll learn the facts about CKD and dialysis care in the U.S., the financial implications for employers and workers, and benefits strategies to help address and manage the condition. 
Register now
. 
 
Sept. 19: Ageism in Industries. 
Ageism remains the open secret in the advertising, marketing, and branding categories. Subtle discrimination is vaguely disguised in commercials and employer branding, especially in the beauty and tech industries. Often the About Us and Meet our Team landing pages can tell you more about a brand than the nicely polished imagery. If you’re an organization that struggles to attract and retain experienced talent, join AARP Senior Advisor Heather Tinsley-Fix and New & Improved Principal Lisa Balser for a discussion on how ageism shows up in marketing and how employers can signal and implement a more inclusive culture. They’ll cover age discrimination trends and how they adversely affect an organization’s strategic goals; the silent signals of ageism in your organization, from client-facing work to internal workflows and decisions; and strategies to become more age-inclusive, not just in your marketing strategy but in creating teams. 
Register now
. 
 
Sept. 21: Manager Ratings Are Wrong: It’s Time for a New Era of Fair, Data-Driven Performance Reviews. 
Personnel is a business’s largest cost, so measuring performance is critical. But research shows that 60% of managers' ratings are based on their own idiosyncrasies. What can be done to make this critical measuring tool more accurate? Or are we doomed to performance reviews being a necessary evil? 
Register now
.
 
Sept. 25: The Future of Employee Engagement and Social Good in Companies. 
We all know that empowering employees to create social impact–whether it be through volunteering, giving, or general acts of kindness–is good for business. So good, in fact, that a global survey conducted by Nielsen found that 66% of respondents were willing to pay more for products and services from companies committed to positive social and environmental impacts. AHarvard Business Review study found that companies with strong CSR programs experienced up to 50% lower employee-turnover rates compared to companies that did not prioritize CSR. As good as the benefits are, executing a successful social-impact program is becoming increasingly challenging because of rapid changes in the tools available, employee expectations, and restrictions on time. Our question: What is next for employee engagement and social good in companies? Our expert speakers will paint a picture of what the future looks like and what companies and leaders should be doing now to prepare. 
Register now
. 
 
Sept. 28: Helping Working Parents Make a Confident Comeback. 
After parental leave, a working parent’s return to the workforce can be a daunting experience. As they adjust to their new roles as parents and professionals, their self-assurance can lapse and stress can rise. In this interactive webinar, we’ll explore how parents can make a more confident comeback to the workforce. We’ll cover topics such as saying good-bye to the elusive work-life balance and instead embracing “life meets work”; establishing and enforcing healthy boundaries that support well-being and self-efficacy; planning for career progression after parental leave; and how leaders can foster a truly family-friendly work culture. 
Register now
.
 
Oct. 10: Why Women’s Health Benefits Are Essential to Retention. 
Women’s health can be a high cost driver for employers. Additionally, offering solutions to improve and support needs specific to women can also be an important factor to retention. But women’s health in general is not just one condition. Join us for this fireside chat in which Dr. Leslie Saltzman, Ovia Health’s chief medical officer, explains the different facets of women’s health (like menopause, fertility, and maternity care management), what areas generate the most ROI, and how employers can offer the deepest, and most all-encompassing benefits to support and delight their employees and medically supported dependents. 
Register now
. 
 
Nov. 9: Bridging the Distance: How Tech Can Boost Engagement and Recognition.
 In a distributed workforce, how can employers promote both team cohesion and making individual employees feel “seen” by their managers and peers? What have business leaders learned in the past two years about which technologies and practices are motivational and informative, vs. fatiguing or counterproductive? 
Register now
.

VIRTUAL CONFERENCES
 
2023
 
Sept. 20: 
Building a Healthy Work Environment to Persevere Through Multiple Challenges
. 
Organizations offering health care and wellness benefits maintain a stronger sense of employee loyalty. Yet health and well-being among employees goes beyond acute or specific physical or mental health needs. How can companies create a culture that emphasizes health through everyday experience? What are the hidden opportunities to nurture this kind of culture? Rather than relying only on standard  benefits to respond in times of unexpected distress, how can organizations address employee needs proactively? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Sept. 27: 
Giving Workers Direction About Skills and Career Development
. 
Many workers yearn to grow and advance in their careers, yet don’t have an understanding of how to develop their skills and experience  for a role with more responsibility. Learning and development can help not only by showing the many possibilities, but also with vision to help employees find the learning and development path that will enable the most fulfilling growth according to their own interests. What can organizations do to deploy coaching in a way that helps not only with short-term goals but also the long arc of a worker’s career? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Oct. 11: 
How HR Technology Can Connect, Motivate, and Recognize the Hybrid Workforce
. 
Most workers have strongly embraced hybrid and remote work arrangements, having settled into sustainable routines that allow them to be productive. But camaraderie and a sense of belonging have proven elusive without meaningful face-to-face contact and team-building opportunities. How can organizations create new structures for in-person gatherings that maintain the comfort of remote or hybrid work, as well as new digital approaches that create the ties that bind? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Nov. 8: 
Casting a Wider Net: Fresh, Productive Approaches to Diversity Recruiting
. 
Many companies fall short of their diversity-hiring goals because they keep looking in the same places–and with the same techniques and expectations. What are the best ways for employers to break out of these patterns? How can they reconsider their job specifications to bring in more non-traditional candidates and prospects who could thrive with a modest amount of training and upskilling? What are the new and innovative ways to strengthen a diverse pipeline? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Dec. 13: 
The Arc of Change for People and Culture in 2024
. 
Recent history affirms that unpredictable events will buffet the workplace of 2024, yet the trajectory of trends in 2023 gives an indication of how organizations will need to be ready for changing expectations among workers and other stakeholders. What are the emerging patterns that leaders should watch in the realms of diversity and inclusion, talent acquisition, employee rewards, learning and development, social responsibility and sustainability? What new points of focus will arrive in the greater field of people and culture? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
2024
 
Jan. 10: A Fresh Commitment to a Culture of Well-Being.
 While many employers recognize the connection between well-being and productivity, creating a healthy balance in the real world of work can be challenging. What are the key choices and thoughtful compromises that must be made for workers to thrive as well as produce? How can managers be trained to make the well-being of their workers a top priority? How can companies get a better sense of which benefits and rewards are most effective–and encourage workers to take advantage of them? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Feb. 14: Getting to the Next Stage of Diversity and Belonging. 
At a time of resistance and corporate austerity, DEI advocates will need to re-energize themselves and their organizations with new ideas, programs, and reasoning for the cause of diversity. What can DEI practitioners learn from companies with consistent success? How are companies changing their policies to respond to court rulings and lawsuits? What practices have brought the most progress in bringing diversity to leadership ranks? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Mar. 4: Employee Engagement: Tapping the Secrets of Energizing Workers. 
Companies want their employees to be enthused and involved, yet employers need to be thoughtful in fostering these qualities in authentic ways. What’s the latest thinking about how employers can understand the motivations of their workers–and how to respond? What are the best methods for recognizing achievement, both individually and among teams? What’s the connection between engagement and job satisfaction? In the hybrid work environment, what binds workers together and wards off anxiety and loneliness? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Apr. 3: Benefits that Fit Individual Needs Without Busting the Budget. 
Having made a commitment to recognize the unique needs of individuals, the secret is in the execution. What are the emerging benefits and rewards that workers are seeking, from fertility care to financial wellness? How can companies use technology to stay in close touch with what individuals are experiencing–and where they need help as a result? How can companies choose among myriad point solutions and innovative new platforms? What are the most cost-effective rewards in terms of investments and outcomes? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
May 22: Employee Retention, Coaching, and Advancement. 
While the pace of job-hopping has eased, employers have a powerful motivation to retain skilled workers, both for financial and cultural reasons. How can employers use new tools, including AI, to gain insights about what’s inspiring their workers to stay committed–or walk out the door? Since attrition is often caused by poor relationships with managers, what are innovative ways for employers to train their workers to be better leaders at a time when workers have higher expectations for job satisfaction? How can technology help make coaching more effective? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
June 12: Bringing Talent Acquisition Into the Digital Age. 
Despite layoffs making headlines now, all the demographic and digital trends point toward tough competition for workers in the future–maybe sooner than most expect. What are the new techniques and tools that talent-acquisition can use to envision the workforce their company will need in the future? What data and insights can HR and TA leaders provide to the company to be ahead of trends? How can companies do a better job of internal recruiting and promoting internal mobility? What are the best practices for hiring based on skills and potential, rather than credentials? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
July 10: Upgrading L&D: The New Tools for Upskilling and Career Mobility. 
As employers put more emphasis on skills as the currency for worker development, they’re seeking new ways to measure them, fill in gaps, and predict the skills needed in the future. How can these new tools, including AI, create better matches between employees and projects? How can employers gain insights from the data they gather? Why do real-world simulations help measure certain skills better than traditional assessments? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
July 17: Innovative Benefits That Support Healthy Families and Caregivers. 
As the pandemic’s caregiving crisis showed, employers found significant gaps in their support for the parents and other caregivers in their workforces. The resulting scramble to help has produced a wealth of new HR policies, benefit offerings, and management practices. Where is the greatest demand for support, as well as the most innovative new methods? What have been the most cost-effective ways to help caregivers of all kinds, including parents as well as “sandwich generation” workers caring for elderly and disabled relatives? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Aug. 7: Enhancing Employee Engagement Through Technology. 
Traditional methods like town-hall meetings and surveys can be effective, but data and well-drawn insights can give top leaders a heads up about evolving patterns and trends in their workforces. How can AI and other technology be deployed in a way that brings new insights yet still respects privacy and the individual human factors at play? What approaches will bring employers new empathy for worker needs, ambitions, and well-being? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Aug. 28: Pursuing Higher Productivity With Human Factors in Mind. 
In a competitive and uncertain climate, most companies need to do more with less. Yet if workers are their greatest asset, employers need to make sure the push for greater output is sustainable. What is the latest thinking about how to measure productivity, the means for stimulating it, and ensuring that workers have the energy to meet their goals–as well as thrive over the long run? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Sept. 18: Building a Corporate Culture That Workers Can Understand. 
Company culture is amorphous yet vital–the shared beliefs, values, traditions and behaviors that drive the actions of individuals and the organization as a whole. Who should be the architects of a company’s culture and how should it be designed and constructed? How should the culture be communicated, broadly and in everyday actions? How should a company start out on a project to evolve its culture in a credible way? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Oct. 16: Modernizing Your Workplace for a More Flexible, Inclusive Era. 
The arrival of hybrid work sent virtually every employer back to the drawing board about what the workplace should look like, including floor plans, digital platforms, meetings, and even office furniture. After more than three years of experimenting, what have innovative companies discovered about what works–and what doesn’t? How have they improved workplace environments to be healthier, as well as more productive? How have these changes affected the goals of diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Nov. 20: Finding and Deploying HR Tech That Will Empower Workers
. The blossoming of innovation in HR technology has given employers untold new abilities to organize, inspire, develop, reward, and care for their workers. Yet this revolution presents new challenges for companies in choosing and supervising these tech tools. How should these tech platforms be evaluated? Which departments of the company should take responsibility–and how can organizations coordinate these moves? How can companies make sure they’re empowering their workers rather than overloading them with adaptation and distraction? 
Register here to attend
. 
 
Dec. 11: Pioneering Approaches to the Future of Work
. The emergence of generative AI in 2023 marked the arrival of a transforming technology that will change human roles, add and subtract jobs, and create astounding new capabilities. How can companies manage the transition, both from the short-term competitive pressures to  long-term corporate survival? How can AI be used to unleash creativity? Where are the areas for abuse, intentional or otherwise? How will digital transformation affect fields from talent acquisition to learning and development? 
Register here to attend
.

subject: 📰 August 2023: Culture-First Newsletter
body:
Complimentary resources and thought leadership for the month of August - delivered directly to your inbox!
 
Providing impactful resources that inspire kindness, deepen understanding, and foster equity in our culturally diverse world — straight to your inbox.
AUGUST 2023
 
 
"Life's most persistent and urgent question is: What are you doing for others?"
 
- Martin Luther King Jr.
Resources
 
New Podcast Episode
In our latest 
Decoded 
podcast episode, Paul Ladipo joined Larry Baker in a brave conversation to  unpack the coded phrase "I don't see color."
Recording & Transcript
 
 
Podcast Revisited
Last season of our 
Brave Conversations
 
podcast, Ellen Bailey and Christian Höferle joined us to discuss creating brave spaces that empower employees to have authentic conversations.
Recording & Transcript
 
 
New Blog Post
In our latest blog post, we delve into what drives conscious inclusion to promote positive working experiences and equitable outcomes for employees.
Read More
 
Additional Resources for Inclusive Leaders:
Article: 
Managing Bias in Talent Review
Article:

Subject:
 FH in Compass
 
Hello Toni and Kendall,
 
I think this is primarily a Compass tech issue but since the correction may have billing implications I’m messaging you both. This is regarding FleishmanHillard and SOWs 2022-53 and 2021-168 and two Fostering Inclusive Leadership sessions.
 
The initial SOW for these two sessions was 2022-53; however, when invoiced, the payment was sent with the PO for SOW 2021-168. Now both of these sessions are listed in Compass under both SOWs. I’m not sure why they are showing up in SOW 2021-168, but I am assuming that it is somehow connected to the billing error (that I made…I think).
 
So based upon Compass, it shows payment for 4 sessions; but in reality, it is only two sessions. What is the best way to correct this in Compass?
 
Tamara

subject: MS Teams: Discovery Call
body:
Hello All, 
 
We are beginning to see an increase in clients requesting to use MS Teams to deliver facilitated content and we each can benefit from getting upskilled. 
 
The purpose of this meeting is to:
Identify what MS Teams questions we have.
Determine what presentation interactions we need to have available in Teams.
Polls, annotations, breakout rooms
What else?
Identify folks that will get answers and upskill other staff members

subject: Brave Conversations x Ollie Lingwood-Craddock
body:
Hi Kendall, 
I thought a good fit for a potential episode for Brave Conversations would focus on Remote Work, Diversity and Inclusion and Employee Burnout. 
I'd like to recommend a potential guest for your show with experience in speaking to the following listeners:
HR professionals
Diversity and Inclusion officers
Managers and executives
 
Speaker Recommendation: 
Ollie Lingwood-Craddock - Over 15 years of Experience in CEO/Director Roles. 
- Expert in Business Transformation 
You can read more about Ollie Lingwood-Craddock on this 
Podfolio page
.
What do you think of these talking points for a potential episode?
Let me know your feedback, I'll be happy to set up a conversation between you.
Looking forward to hearing from you,
Jenny
Podcast Success Manager at Pikkal

subject: Scoro Update: Project Budget Charts
body:
Good news! Your Scoro site lcw.scoro.com has been updated! Smart budgeting is crucial for project success. So this month, we’re ...
 
 
 
Log in → 
 
Good news! Your Scoro site 
lcw.scoro.com
 has been updated!
Smart budgeting is crucial for project success. So this month, we’re calling in data visualization to add another dimension to budget planning in Scoro. Our new project charts empower you to plan, track and analyze the budgeted hours even more proactively. 
See what we’ve been up to!
Charts in the project view
To give you further insights into budget burn and progress, we’ve enhanced the project view with two 
charts
. These help you understand how well you’re keeping to your budget 
time-wise
. We’ve placed the charts under the 
Budget insights
 toggle along with the ‘Quoted vs actual’ table.
The 
budget burn chart
 visualizes project progress over time. It’s there to help you detect potential overservicing ahead of time and course correct promptly by replanning or renegotiating the project scope. 
 The 
budget breakdown chart
 helps you track the use of the time budget on a 
role level
 to ensure you stick to the scope. 
 Both charts also include a 
forecast dimension
. 
Read more
 
Ticket tracking in Help Center
Our Help Center is the go-to place whenever you need additional information about Scoro or want to submit a support ticket. Now you can also create yourself an account in our Help Center to conveniently track and manage all your support requests in one place. No more digging through the mailbox as all current and past requests and related communication are stored safely under your account. 
Read more
 about the Help Center account. 
Read more
 
See our blog post for more details!
We do our very best to make Scoro better every day, so we really appreciate your feedback. Let us know what you think at 
help@scoro.com
.
Yours truly,
Team Scoro
 
 
 
© 2023 Scoro Software. | 
www.scoro.com
 
Scoro Software Ltd | The Frames, 1 Phipp Street, EC2A 4PS | London, United Kingdom 
If you need assistance or have any questions, please contact our 
Customer Support
.

subject: FH in Compass
body:
Hello Toni and Kendall,
 
I think this is primarily a Compass tech issue but since the correction may have billing implications I’m messaging you both. This is regarding FleishmanHillard and SOWs 2022-53 and 2021-168 and two Fostering Inclusive Leadership sessions.
 
The initial SOW for these two sessions was 2022-53; however, when invoiced, the payment was sent with the PO for SOW 2021-168. Now both of these sessions are listed in Compass under both SOWs. I’m not sure why they are showing up in SOW 2021-168, but I am assuming that it is somehow connected to the billing error (that I made…I think).
 
So based upon Compass, it shows payment for 4 sessions; but in reality, it is only two sessions. What is the best way to correct this in Compass?
 
Tamara
 
 
Tamara Thorpe
(she/her)
Principal Consultant
LCW

subject: How will you take advantage of the growing market for AI?
body:
Learn how you can prepare for technological disruptions and the long-term results of them.
 
 
 
 
Webinar
Our Automated Future:
Learning to Adapt, and Thrive, in the Era of Intelligent Machines
  
Tuesday, August 22
9 a.m. PT | 12 p.m. ET
Get on the guest list
 
 
Artificial intelligence has been with us for decades. But today's machines are gaining the ability to learn from data and make sophisticated predictions—more cheaply, and more accurately, than human beings.
To understand technological shifts such as this, experts turn to Ajay Agrawal. A leading authority in AI, Ajay will break down how you can prepare for technological disruptions and the long-term results of them.
Join this live webinar to also learn how to:
Take advantage of the growing market for AI
Allocate capital and investments today to best prepare for tomorrow

 and we will send you a link to the recording.

From:

b.cardenas@lcwmail.com
>
Sent:
 Thursday, August 10, 2023 3:05:47 PM
To:
 Elijah Anderson <
eanderson@teamlogicit.com
>; Kendall Washington <
k.washington@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: License listing
 
 
Hi Elijah, 
 
I shared the list you provided with the consultants and CEOs. The folks highlighted in red no longer need a license. They folks highlighted in yellow don’t either, but I want to make sure their inbox can still go to their manager. I added a column (column A) with the name of the person their inbox should be transferred to. 
 
Should we schedule another meeting next week to talk through the pricing, what we were paying vs. what we will be paying after the changes, etc.?
 
I also reached out to Jake today and he said he never received a FedEx box and he still has his laptop. Here is his address:
 
Jake
Pieczynski
1919 S. Wabash Ave
Apt. 618
Chicago
IL
60616
 
Can you send him another box please?
 
Briza Cardenas  
(she/her)
Chief of Staff, Office of the CEO
LCW

From:
 Elijah Anderson <
eanderson@teamlogicit.com
> 
Sent:
 Thursday, August 10, 2023 12:15 PM
To:
 Kendall Washington <
k.washington@lcwmail.com
>; Briza Cardenas <
b.cardenas@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 License listing
 
Hello, 
  Here’s a list of everyone’s licensing currently. I can typically get you a discount on all licensing, except for teams voice licensing (I’m sure that will change soon and I’ll let you know when it does). For business premium licensing it’s $264 annually if you buy it from Microsoft and I resell it for $252/annually. On pretty much any annual license I can offer 5% discount. If you go through the attached list and maybe highlight in red those people who do not need a license I can go through the process of removing licenses and make sure the LCW credit card on file with Microsoft no longer gets charged unnecessarily. Also, I talked with the team and moving from lcwmail.com to lcwinclusion.com or whatever domain you choose would involve a full email migration. It would be something we’d do over a weekend and would have minimal impact on the users. We can definitely assist you with that and typical guidance is to budget an hour per mailbox.
 
Also I can see that the box was delivered to Jake via Fedex, tracking number 781059794350 but it doesn’t look like he’s sent it back, tracking number 791373600964
 
Thanks! 
 
Elijah J. Anderson
Owner
Team
Logic
IT – Lincoln Square
312-736-0981 – Office
312-350-4651 – Cell
eanderson@teamlogicit.com
www.teamlogicit.com/lincolnsquareIL
    
 
We build our business on referrals. If you know of someone who has technology concerns, please let them know about us. We’d like to help. 
 
I welcome you to follow us on Facebook as well, thanks!

subject: New at Zoom: August 2023
body:
Explore the latest Zoom features, product webinars, blogs, events, customer stories, and more.
 
 
 
  
Zoom Monthly Updates
 
How our terms of service and practices apply to AI features
As part of our commitment to transparency and user control, we are providing clarity on our approach to two essential aspects of our services: Zoom’s AI features and customer content sharing for product improvement purposes. Our goal is to enable Zoom account owners and administrators to have control over these features and decisions, and we’re here to shed light on how we do that and how that affects certain customer groups. 
Recent terms of service changes
 
Latest news
How tos
 
How to cut IT costs without impacting productivity
Learn how consolidating your communications with Zoom can help you get the time and money back that you need to future-proof your business.
Do more with less   
 
Conversation Intelligence
 
Sales leader’s guide to revenue growth with AI
Explore how conversational intelligence can streamline your operations and lead to revenue growth.
Drive more productivity and growth   
 
Contact Center
 
Introducing Zoom Workforce Management
Discover how you can streamline communications, manage agent needs, and transform your customer experience all from a single, unified platform.
Improve the customer and agent experience   
 
Webinars
August 30 
What’s New at Zoom
10 a.m. PT | 1 p.m. ET
Register
 
Reduce cost while scaling to meet business demands with Zoom Team Chat
On-demand
Watch now
 
See all webinars   
 
Events
  
Zoomtopia, Oct. 3-4 | San Jose, CA and virtually 
Discover new ways to improve collaboration, make more impactful decisions, and deepen customer relationships at Zoomtopia, our incredible, award-winning event. You’re in for the most exciting, interactive, and inspiring event of the year, for decision-makers across industries!
Get an exclusive look into the latest innovations shaping the future of work and the workplace.
Discover how to leverage AI to create a more efficient and flexible work environment.
Learn from industry thought leaders about the tech trends that matter to you.
Register
 
Customer spotlight
  
Glassdoor
Learn how Glassdoor was able to create an engaging hybrid event experience for employees.

subject: Now Live: Zoom Customer Success Community Forum
body:
Hi Kendall, 
In case you missed it, we’re excited to announce the launch of the Customer Success Forum on the Zoom Community!  
What is the Zoom Community?  
The 
Zoom Community 
is a hub for users to find answers, seek support, and receive guidance from fellow Zoom users and Zoom product experts.  
What is the Customer Success Forum? 
Located within the Zoom Community, the Customer Success Forum is a collaborative place to share customer success stories, learn about upcoming events, and exchange use cases for helpful ways to use Zoom features. 
Zoom customers and experts alike are already on the Customer Success Forum exchanging knowledge and best practices, so sign in today to learn more and maximize Zoom’s many capabilities. 
Happy Zooming,
Zoom Success Advisor
Click 
here
 to unsubscribe from this list or manage your preferences 
here
.

subject: [Live Demo] Getting Started with Zoom
body:
This beginner-friendly webinar will provide you with all the essential knowledge you need to get started with Zoom!
 
 
 
 
Webinar
Getting Started with Zoom
  
Thursday, August 10
10:00 a.m. PT | 1:00 p.m. ET
Register now
 
 
Join us for this informative session and take the first step towards becoming a Zoom expert! This interactive webinar will teach you the basics of the Zoom platform, allowing you to enhance your team’s collaboration and engagement.
Our Zoom expert will walk you through beginner and advanced features such as:
Scheduling and joining meetings
Screen sharing
Team Chat collaboration features 
Breakout Rooms 
Launching Polls 
Virtual Backgrounds 
  
Register now
  
Can't make it? 
Register anyway
 and we'll email you the recording!

subject: Slido Monthly | 3 ways to nurture employee sense of belonging
body:
Learn how TomTom uses Slido
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
 
 
View in browser
 
Nurture employee sense of belonging 
Since its startup days, geolocation services provider 
TomTom
 has kept its focus firmly on people.
As an organization, TomTom is committed to helping people find places where they can truly belong.
This month, we're sharing how Slido is helping nurture that sense of belonging and psychological safety across their organization.
Hope you'll find it as inspiring as we did! 
 
Breaking hierarchies, building bonds
Learn how TomTom uses Slido to break down barriers between leaders and employees. 
Read full story
 
Three ways TomTom uses Slido 
1. Build trust with Q&A sessions 👷
Slido is democratic. You can easily see what’s the most important issue or the top themes according to your people.
Sometimes people raise challenging questions or want to understand things more thoroughly. Learn 
5 ways how to deal with difficult employee questions
 during Q&As. 
 
2. Promote transparency 📣
People have been able to see the positive results of speaking up and sharing their thoughts. It's built a trusting culture, which is really strong. 
Regular employee engagement surveys are a great way to learn how your team is doing and track progress. Create a 
survey in Slido
 and get inspired by Gallup's 12 
employee engagement survey questions
. 
 
3. Lead people in a hybrid world 🧗
Interaction is what takes your employee relationships to the next level. 
With teams spread across the globe and busy schedules, it's never been more important to focus on connection. Simple check-in can help 
read the room
 and foster relationships.
 
 
Equal experience for all participants in Teams
No more switching tabs or voting via phone for participants without a Microsoft account. Everyone can now vote comfortably directly in Teams and see Slido when shared on stage. 
Other than Teams improvements, we've got a new Slido launch screen in Webex. Check out all the details in 
July's Product News edition
. 🎉 
Add Slido to Teams 
Do you have a story on how Slido has helped your organization or meetings? 
We’d love to hear from you
.💚 
P.S. Did you find the content helpful?
If you have any feedback, we'd love to hear your thoughts!
Very helpful 
It's OK

subject: RE: Rebranded Microlearning
body:
Hey Keri,
 
Thanks for this! I’ll make the changes and get back to you.
 
Have a great weekend!
 
From:
 Keri Luo <k.luo@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Friday, August 4, 2023 3:05 PM
To:
 Kendall Washington <k.washington@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Rebranded Microlearning 
 
Hi Kendall, How are you?
 
Dustin asked me to review the rebranded Microlearning and give some feedback. I browsed through. I must say they look fantastic! 
I would like to offer two suggestions for your consideration:
I really appreciate your color choice, the dark blue and light blue (green-blue) combination, as they are also my favorite colors to use. I prefer cool colors over warm colors. However, I understand that some people (especially Chuck) might prefer bright and colorful layouts. So, If you want to make them more colorful, here's my suggestion: 
You can use different colors for each Microlearning home page hero image, instead of only using blue. For instance, you could choose one brand color for each Microlearning, resulting in five Microlearning, each having a different color. Additionally, consider using the same color as the home page for the bar/frame of the hero image on subpages. Alternatively, if you wish to keep the blue color for the home page, you could use different color bars for the images for the subpages. Or, you can only add a bright color, such as orange, to the buttons.  I hope they are easy tweaks for you.
 
Please ensure that the body text font is consistent throughout and set to "Poppins."
 
Let me know if you have any questions or need further clarification. 
 
I sent Dustin a separate email and giving him some feedback for videos as well. 
 
Have a great weekend!
 
~Keri
 
 
 
Keri  Luo
(she/her)
Visual Designer
LCW
