subject: What's New at Zoom | July 2023 Recap
body:
Dear Kendall, 
Whether it's new products and features or courses that teach you to use Zoom better, we are constantly evolving to improve your experience. To help keep you up to date, we have summarized some key new things you should know below. 
Download
 the latest version of the Zoom desktop client to access all these features and more. 
For more resources to help you stay up to date, check out: 
Preview notes
 – A list of upcoming features. This page is only available to Zoom account owners and admins; you must sign in to view them.
Release notes
 – A complete list of past releases across the Zoom platform. 
If you have questions about the features and announcements outlined below, please reply directly to this email.
*Note: Some products and features may not be available to all customers. 
Zoom Learning Center Updates 
Discover updated Zoom Rooms courses - 
The Zoom Learning Center team recently updated the 
Zoom Rooms catalog
 to include information on all the latest and greatest features and enhancements. Refresh your memory on Zoom Rooms features, or learn something new like how you can reserve a Zoom Room with Workspace Reservation! 
Zoom Community  
The 
Customer Success Forum
 on the Zoom Community is now live!
 Launched in 2021, the 
Zoom Community
 is a hub for users to find answers, seek support, and receive guidance from fellow Zoom users and Zoom product experts. In the new Customer Success Forum, users will find a collaborative place to share success stories, learn about upcoming events, and exchange helpful ways to use Zoom features, all in one centralized, easily accessible location. Join the forum and learn more today!
Key Highlights from Zoom’s July Releases  
Zoom Web
 Updates 
Set default Team Chat channels for users
 -
 Account owners and admins can set up to 5 default Team Chat channels, to which all new and existing users will automatically be added. The chosen channels must be public channels and users can choose to leave these default channels. 
Zoom Phone
 Updates 
Advanced encryption for voicemails -
 Once advanced encryption for Zoom Phone voicemail is enabled, voicemail messages are received and recorded by Zoom servers which encrypt them with keys only known to their intended recipients’ devices. If admins enable the Escrow feature within advanced encryption for voicemails, admins will now be able to access these keys and users voicemails. Shared Line Appearance, Shared Line Group, Call Queue, or Auto Receptionist voicemail are not supported. Additionally, functionalities like email to voicemail, transcriptions, and the ability to check voicemails through dialing or the web are disabled when this feature is enabled. To utilize this feature, users must have a Power Pack license. Only admins with appropriate permissions can manage these voicemails.
Zoom Events
 Updates 
Attendee Companion app for Zoom - 
Attendees can join hybrid events using the companion app. This app allows them to attend an event in person or virtually without leaving Zoom Events. They can find, bookmark, and attend sessions in hybrid events. Attendees can navigate the physical space using maps and digital guides and switch between in-person and virtual webinar/meeting streams. During hybrid events, attendees can connect with in-person and virtual attendees. The companion app is available for iOS and Android devices. This feature may not be immediately available, as it is dependent on a backend server update. 
Security questions authentication for registration
 -
 Hosts can enable security questions for registrants when creating an event. Security questions apply to all registrants regardless of how they join (i.e., sign in to Zoom/IDP or fast join). The host can choose questions from a list of security questions (a template of 10 questions) and can customize up to 3 security questions. The questions will appear on the registration page as a mandatory item. Registrants must pick at least one question from the list and answer it to complete registration. The answer to each question will be associated with unique users, and the answer will be stored safely on the Zoom Events platform. After authentication at joining, registrants must answer the question they chose at registration. Only the registrant has the answer to the security question. If the registrant loses the answer, they will also lose access to the assigned ticket and cannot join the event. Registrants can contact the host for help and can register another ticket from the event detail page.
Zoom IQ for Sales
 Updates 
Email compose with Zoom IQ for Sales
 -
 Account owners and admins can enable or disable users' option to use Zoom IQ to create follow-up emails directly from the Zoom IQ for Sales Deals page. This setting is available at the account level and is disabled by default. This feature is currently not available for users with External IQ Admin and Zoom IQ Collaborator roles. 
Zoom Contact Center
 Updates 
Support for regions -
 Account owners and admins can create regions to organize users based on their location and apply voice routing settings specific to each location. This feature must be enabled by Zoom. 
Auto answer with queue default greeting - 
Account owners and admins can improve the call handling efficiency by implementing the auto answer feature for voice engagements. With auto answer, agents can automatically connect with callers, reducing the number of clicks required and providing a standardized caller experience. It also eliminates the need for agents to repeat the same greeting on every engagement, ensuring consistent greetings. 
Video channel for integrations -
 The Zendesk and Salesforce integrations for Zoom Contact Center support the video channel. As a result, agents can receive incoming video engagements, make outbound video calls, upgrade a voice call to video call, and chat with the consumer using in-video chat during the video engagement within the integration. During an incoming/outbound video engagement, the agent can see the customer screen pop within the CRM based on the 'email address' match. Configuration settings have been updated with video channel settings for Screen pop and search settings.  
Workspace Reservation
 Updates 
Workspaces admin management of reservations - 
Admins can add, change, or delete reservations at the building level. They can also override users' reservations in the building. Admins can book a workspace for a user (without needing to set up delegation), change a current workspace reservation of a user, and delete a user's current reservation. The user will receive a  notification if a change was made to the reservation by an admin. 
Configure a permanent desk -
 Account owners and admins can assign a user a permanent desk. Permanent desks are not reservable and will always display the assigned user at that desk. This feature displays users, who come into the office every day, and their permanent desks on the floor map. 
Business Announcements 
Zoom Software Lifecycle Policy -
 We plan to enforce the fourth round of our Software Lifecycle Policy on August 5, 2023, for all products and services, starting with the minimum versions referenced in the table found 
here
. Users running an end-of-life version after August 5 will not be able to join meetings via the Zoom Client and will be prompted to update or join from the Web browser. As always, we highly recommend you regularly download and update to the latest version of Zoom software by checking for updates within the Zoom desktop client or by navigating to 
zoom.us/download
 to take advantage of all our latest security and functionality features. Note: The end-of-life enforcement for Zoom Room Controllers on Windows UWP has been extended to August 5, 2023.  
End of Life for JSON Web Token (JWT) App Type in Zoom Marketplace -
 As a reminder, Zoom disabled the ability to create new JWT apps on June 1, 2023. Developers have until September 1, 2023 to migrate their JWT-based solutions to the new Server-to-Server OAuth or OAuth app types. For more information, please see the 
JWT migration guide
 and 
JWT deprecation FAQ
. 
Happy Zooming,
Zoom Success Advisor

here
 to unsubscribe from this list or manage your preferences 
here
.

subject: 5 Episode Titles for Brave Conversations
body:
Hi Kendall 
I've included a list of potential talking points from Ollie Lingwood-Craddock for Brave Conversations that could become episode ideas. 
Please take a look at let me know which you think would work for a future podcast episode:
= = = = = = = = = = = = = 
1. 
The Importance of Employee Feedback in Organizational Change:
 Discuss how effective communication is vital during times of change, and why it can be transformative for leaders to have an authentic dialogue with employees to facilitate business transformation. 
2. 
Unveiling Hidden Insights:
 Ollie emphasizes the transformative power of unlocking actionable insights from people data. By delving into the rich pool of information within organizations, leaders can gain board-level insights that fuel informed decision-making, drive positive outcomes, and uncover hidden opportunities for growth and improvement.
3. 
The Future of Work and Employee Engagement:
 Discuss the big societal changes happening in work and culture right now, such as the rise of remote work and the importance of diversity and inclusion. Use this as an opportunity to showcase how Rungway's platform can help organizations build a more inclusive and engaged workforce by providing a safe space for dialogue and feedback. 
= = = = = = = = = = = = = 
What do you think? 
Would your audience like to hear more about these?
Happy to set up a chat to see what would really fly for your listeners.
Looking forward to hearing from you, 
Jenny
from Jenny Ortega
Podcast Success Manager
Pikkal & Co

From:

help@scoro.com
> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, May 10, 2023 3:07 AM
To:
 Chuck Adams <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Kendall Washington <
k.washington@lcwmail.com
>; Jennifer Barbieri <
j.barbieri@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 [Scoro] Re: Reporting Help
 
Hi Chuck,
 
Thank you for getting back to me!
 
The invoice report will count all invoices created in the time period you selected - it doesn't consider the line dates on the invoice. If you have already created an invoice for quote lines in June and July, then the report will consider those as well. Currently, the invoice report is only looking at the invoice "Issued date" and the total sum of the invoice. 
However, you can use additional filters in the report, such as the "Accounting status", or you can look at the invoice due date instead of the issued date. 
 
For example, if you select "Issued date: All dates" and "Due date: Previous month", you can see what your revenue for April should be. 
 
 
 
It is definitely fair to say that Quotes show us planned future revenue while Invoices show us the actual revenue.
 
This invoice 
https://lcw.scoro.com/invoices/view/844
 shows up in the report because currently, the report shows invoices with all accounting statuses. You would need to filter out invoices with the accounting status you wish to see. You can do that here:
 
 
 
It's very hard to say what the most accurate report for forecasting revenue would be for your business, as I don't know the details of your process and when you actually invoice the quotes. One way to look at it would be that all quotes with a successful status (I don't know your system for statuses) should be considered as future revenue. So, you can use the "Quotes periodized" report and filter out quotes with a successful status to predict revenue.
 
Please let me know if you have any questions, and I'd be happy to assist!
 
Kindest regards, 
 
 
                Anna-Justina K | Customer Support Specialist
Scoro | 
www.scoro.com
  | Help videos and manuals: support.scoro.com

scoro.com/4-day-work-week

On 9 May 2023 at 13:46:26 UTC, Chuck Adams 
c.adams@lcwmail.com
 wrote:
Anna-Justina – Thank you for your prompt response.
 
The Quote line/Invoice explanation makes sense and I think it confirms what I thought. 
 
A quote with lines of delivery dates of Apr, May, Jun and Jul will only count Apr and May (if already invoiced) in the invoice report currently. It won’t add in Jun and Jul until after the invoices have been submitted to accounting. Is that correct?
 
Would it be fair to say that Quotes show us planned future revenue while Invoices show us the present AR?
 
What about something like 
https://lcw.scoro.com/invoices/view/844
 which is in draft accounting status? Why does it show up on the Invoice report?
 
In the end, what report/filter would you use to forecast revenue as accurately as possible?
 
Chuck
 
______________________________________
Chuck Adams 
Co-CEO and Managing Principal

From:
 Anna-Justina K (Support) <
help@scoro.com
> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, May 9, 2023 5:51 AM
To:
 Chuck Adams <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Kendall Washington <
k.washington@lcwmail.com
>; Jennifer Barbieri <
j.barbieri@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 [Scoro] Re: Reporting Help
 
Hi Chuck,
 
Thank you for reaching out to us!
 
I'm happy to help with this. The Quote report will show all quotes with quote lines in the time period you selected (this quarter) and the statuses you selected. The Invoice report will show all invoices created in the time period you selected. So my question would be that do you invoice all quotes within the same month they were created? If not, then you can't really compare the two reports. 
 
For accurate reports, it's important to understand which dates to look at. If we take a closer look at the invoices created in April, for example, for Aflac Worldwide Headquarters and 
Invoice no. 17240335
, we can see that the last line on the invoice is dated 01/30/2023. This means that even though the invoice was issued in April, it includes quote lines from January. Therefore, if we are comparing quote lines from April (as in your Quote report) and invoices issued in April, the sums can't and shouldn't match.
 
The information is correct in both reports. You can use the "Quotes periodized" report to predict your income in specific time periods, but the actual income will depend on when the invoices are issued and when you actually receive payment. So the accuracy of the forecast will depend on when you invoice your quotes.
 
I hope this makes sense, but please let me know if you have any questions or need further information.
 
Kindest regards,
 
 
 
 
 
                Anna-Justina K | Customer Support Specialist
Scoro |

c.adams@lcwmail.com
 wrote:
Hello – 
 
We are trying to find the most accurate quarterly/yearly projections in the various Scoro reports and we are seeing some inconsistencies in two that we intitially thought would be good for that.
 
The quote report below (screenshot shows how filters are set) seems to show 10 quotes for April valued at $276,376.92 while the Invoice report, further down, shows 20 Invoices values at $592,147.15. There are also discrepancies in the May and June number between the two reports. My thinking is that since we are past April the Invoices are accurate (it also matches what in QBO accounting software), but that the Quotes for May and June are only 
forecasts
 since we haven’t started submitting them for invoicing yet.
 
Is this correct? Am I missing some logic here? We just want the most accurate forecasts we can find in the system and are still trying to find that in the system. Help will be appreciated.

subject: 🎙️ Decoded: New Podcast Release
body:
Join us in unpacking the phrase "I don't see color" with Paul Ladipo from Critical Conversations Consulting, LLC.
 
New Episode Release
Recording & Transcript
 
"I don't see color."
“I don’t see color” is sometimes viewed as a non-discriminatory, “politically correct” approach to interactions with people of color. But in reality, there’s a difference between understanding a person’s inherent value and being mindful of the challenges and perspectives each unique identity brings to the conversation.
 
To help us unpack this phrase, Host Larry Baker (he/him) is joined by Paul Ladipo (he/him), who will use their own lived experiences to explain how the phrase actually perpetuates racism through willful ignorance.
Featuring:
 
Paul Ladipo
Founder and Owner
Critical Conversations Consulting, LLC
LinkedIn

From:

help@scoro.com
> 
Sent:
 Wednesday, May 10, 2023 3:07 AM
To:
 Chuck Adams <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Kendall Washington <
k.washington@lcwmail.com
>; Jennifer Barbieri <
j.barbieri@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 [Scoro] Re: Reporting Help
 
Hi Chuck,
 
Thank you for getting back to me!
 
The invoice report will count all invoices created in the time period you selected - it doesn't consider the line dates on the invoice. If you have already created an invoice for quote lines in June and July, then the report will consider those as well. Currently, the invoice report is only looking at the invoice "Issued date" and the total sum of the invoice. 
However, you can use additional filters in the report, such as the "Accounting status", or you can look at the invoice due date instead of the issued date. 
 
For example, if you select "Issued date: All dates" and "Due date: Previous month", you can see what your revenue for April should be. 
 
 
 
It is definitely fair to say that Quotes show us planned future revenue while Invoices show us the actual revenue.
 
This invoice 
https://lcw.scoro.com/invoices/view/844
 shows up in the report because currently, the report shows invoices with all accounting statuses. You would need to filter out invoices with the accounting status you wish to see. You can do that here:
 
 
 
It's very hard to say what the most accurate report for forecasting revenue would be for your business, as I don't know the details of your process and when you actually invoice the quotes. One way to look at it would be that all quotes with a successful status (I don't know your system for statuses) should be considered as future revenue. So, you can use the "Quotes periodized" report and filter out quotes with a successful status to predict revenue.
 
Please let me know if you have any questions, and I'd be happy to assist!
 
Kindest regards, 
 
 
                Anna-Justina K | Customer Support Specialist
Scoro | 
www.scoro.com
  | Help videos and manuals: support.scoro.com

On 9 May 2023 at 13:46:26 UTC, Chuck Adams 
c.adams@lcwmail.com
 wrote:
Anna-Justina – Thank you for your prompt response.
 
The Quote line/Invoice explanation makes sense and I think it confirms what I thought. 
 
A quote with lines of delivery dates of Apr, May, Jun and Jul will only count Apr and May (if already invoiced) in the invoice report currently. It won’t add in Jun and Jul until after the invoices have been submitted to accounting. Is that correct?
 
Would it be fair to say that Quotes show us planned future revenue while Invoices show us the present AR?
 
What about something like 
https://lcw.scoro.com/invoices/view/844
 which is in draft accounting status? Why does it show up on the Invoice report?
 
In the end, what report/filter would you use to forecast revenue as accurately as possible?
 
Chuck
 
______________________________________
Chuck Adams 
Co-CEO and Managing Principal

From:
 Anna-Justina K (Support) <
help@scoro.com
> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, May 9, 2023 5:51 AM
To:
 Chuck Adams <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Kendall Washington <
k.washington@lcwmail.com
>; Jennifer Barbieri <
j.barbieri@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 [Scoro] Re: Reporting Help
 
Hi Chuck,
 
Thank you for reaching out to us!
 
I'm happy to help with this. The Quote report will show all quotes with quote lines in the time period you selected (this quarter) and the statuses you selected. The Invoice report will show all invoices created in the time period you selected. So my question would be that do you invoice all quotes within the same month they were created? If not, then you can't really compare the two reports. 
 
For accurate reports, it's important to understand which dates to look at. If we take a closer look at the invoices created in April, for example, for Aflac Worldwide Headquarters and 
Invoice no. 17240335
, we can see that the last line on the invoice is dated 01/30/2023. This means that even though the invoice was issued in April, it includes quote lines from January. Therefore, if we are comparing quote lines from April (as in your Quote report) and invoices issued in April, the sums can't and shouldn't match.
 
The information is correct in both reports. You can use the "Quotes periodized" report to predict your income in specific time periods, but the actual income will depend on when the invoices are issued and when you actually receive payment. So the accuracy of the forecast will depend on when you invoice your quotes.
 
I hope this makes sense, but please let me know if you have any questions or need further information.
 
Kindest regards,
 
 
 
 
 
                Anna-Justina K | Customer Support Specialist
Scoro |

c.adams@lcwmail.com
 wrote:
Hello – 
 
We are trying to find the most accurate quarterly/yearly projections in the various Scoro reports and we are seeing some inconsistencies in two that we intitially thought would be good for that.
 
The quote report below (screenshot shows how filters are set) seems to show 10 quotes for April valued at $276,376.92 while the Invoice report, further down, shows 20 Invoices values at $592,147.15. There are also discrepancies in the May and June number between the two reports. My thinking is that since we are past April the Invoices are accurate (it also matches what in QBO accounting software), but that the Quotes for May and June are only 
forecasts
 since we haven’t started submitting them for invoicing yet.
 
Is this correct? Am I missing some logic here? We just want the most accurate forecasts we can find in the system and are still trying to find that in the system. Help will be appreciated.
 
Quote Report
 
 
Invoice Report

If Melissa can go to System -> About and send a screenshot of what it say regarding the device I can help come up with a approximate value. Based on the other devices I’m assuming about $500.

We shouldn’t be paying for the MS Suite. The contractors just need an LCW email address. It may be worth confirming with Tech if we can get folks LCW email addresses without a full subscription. Hi team, I added a column (column A in yellow) and made notes about each license. There are a few dozen marked “client” (most of your names in blue) and others marked “facilitator” or “contractor.”
 
For the names marked CLIENT (below) I believe we had licenses related to our ability to interface via Teams, perhaps? Although by that logic BSC should be listed, and they are not.
 
CLIENTS
We need to ask the client relationship manager of each of these organizations if these licenses are needed: 
J&J, Northwestern, Ubisoft, The Learning Gym, Steel Global
 
 
FACILITATORS
For facilitators I believe we had ms accounts so they can interact with our clients with a united LCW front (using our email). We should make an executive decision about whether we want this to continue. I think it is very valuable to do so.
 
 
I have still managed to tag 35 accounts as NOT NEEDED (some of these are duplicates of the lists above)
 
 
 
Let me know if I can support any further, happy to coordinate the communications with the client relationship managers (a few of whom are on this email lol).
 
Thanks,
Sarah
